Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative: Toward a Test Bed for Heavy Vehicle Cyber Security Experimentation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Heavy vehicles, such as trucks and buses, are part of the US critical infrastructure and carry out a significant portion of commercial and private business operations. Little effort has been invested in cyber security for these assets. If an adversary gains access to the vehicle's Controller Area Network (CAN), attacks can be launched that can affect critical vehicle electronic components. Traditionally, physical access to a heavy vehicle was required to access the CAN. However, wireless devices are also installed on heavy vehicles, which open trucks and busses to remote wireless cyber attacks. This project explores cyber security vulnerabilities related to wireless devices that communicate on the CAN. For identified threats, researchers determine the proper mitigation strategies, including where and how they are best deployed. To demonstrate potential exploits and subsequent trust in proposed mitigation strategies, this project designs and implements a scalable, high-fidelity test bed using actual heavy vehicle electronic control units, such as engine and brake controllers. The test bed includes built-in mechanisms for remote access and secure information delivery to allow for collaboration among researchers at different sites. The results of the research, including the potential to extend the test bed with other components, can impact cyber security analysis for other industries that use CAN, such as building automation, medical devices, and manufacturing.

The SAE J1939 communication network in heavy vehicles is based on CAN and has open documentation for packet definition and transmission. This openness may be exploited for creating spoofed J1939 messages. Heavy vehicle owners utilize third-party systems, such as remote telematics, that introduce new J1939 enabled modules, which can potentially be subverted by an adversary. This project uses these systems to gain remote access and attack another CAN connected electronic control unit. Packet sniffing is performed as the telematics system connects wirelessly to the CAN to determine if fake packets can be inserted. Research includes examining different designs, configurations, and deployments of intrusion detection systems to best thwart such remote attacks using the developed test bed. One challenge is to develop algorithms that can act in real-time with deployed test bed hardware. Research includes developing scientific strategies to measure the temporal response of the cyber actions in the test bed and the reaction time of any intrusion detection system, so that bounds can be determined based on the ability to conduct a remote cyber operation on a J1939 network.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Heavy vehicles, such as trucks and buses, are part of the US critical infrastructure and carry out a significant portion of commercial and private business operations. If an adversary gains access to the vehicle’s Controller Area Network (CAN), attacks can be launched that can affect critical vehicle electronic components. Traditionally, physical access to a heavy vehicle was required to access the CAN. However, wireless devices are also installed on heavy vehicles, which open trucks and busses to remote wireless cyber attacks. This project explores cyber security vulnerabilities related to wireless devices that communicate on the CAN. To demonstrate potential exploits and subsequent trust in proposed mitigation strategies, this project designs and implements a scalable, high-fidelity test bed using actual heavy vehicle electronic control units (ECUs), such as engine and brake controllers. Each ECU is wired to a dedicated, combined sensor and actuator simulator component to emulate the communication and electrical environment of a heavy vehicle.

The test bed includes built-in mechanisms for remote access and secure information delivery to allow for collaboration among researchers at different sites. Using an Ethernet network adaptor on an embedded microcontroller, the test bed contains an intermediate data processing component that passes and transforms data to and from the ECUs and testbed web application interface. This connectivity allowed for the development of a web application interface for user-specific experiment construction, scheduling, data storage, data retrieval, and visualization providing a full pass through the experimentation platform.  From the web application interface, the user can (a) schedule an experiment for a set duration, (b) design the experiment by inserting requested features and instantiating predefined parameters, (c) view the entirety of the CAN log, and (d) view graphic visualizations of the data. For example, the testbed can visualize what would happen when a vehicle drives at 65 mph and the brake is applied all the way to the floor. Denial of service attacks and injection attacks on the truck ECUs can be performed by invoking interface’s ability to send user-defined CAN messages on the bus at set intervals. Using Unified Diagnostic Services (UDS), it is possible to update the engine controller and change the Vehicle Identification Number (VIN).  The results of the research, including the potential to extend the test bed with other components, can impact cyber security analysis for other industries that use CAN, such as building automation, medical devices, and manufacturing.

In addition to presenting their work in various forums, undergraduate and graduate students working on the project participated in the Society of Automotive Engineering (SAE/Battelle) CyberAuto Challenge in Detroit, MI in July 2018. Students also participated in the second annual CyberTruck Challenge in Warren, Michigan, in June 2018. Weeklong summer boot camps for undergraduates participating in the annual University of Tulsa Undergraduate Research Challenge were conducted in heavy vehicle cyber security to introduce the research area. New graduate courses have been introduced and team-taught by mechanical engineering and computer science faculty to provide a multi-disciplinary perspective on heavy vehicles as cyber physical systems, cyber security, and vehicle communication networks. 


Last Modified: 07/05/2019
Modified by: Rosanne F Gamble
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Heavy vehicles, such as trucks and buses, are part of the US critical infrastructure and carry out a significant portion of commercial and private business operations. If an adversary gains access to the vehicle?s Controller Area Network (CAN), attacks can be launched that can affect critical vehicle electronic components. Traditionally, physical access to a heavy vehicle was required to access the CAN. However, wireless devices are also installed on heavy vehicles, which open trucks and busses to remote wireless cyber attacks. This project explores cyber security vulnerabilities related to wireless devices that communicate on the CAN. To demonstrate potential exploits and subsequent trust in proposed mitigation strategies, this project designs and implements a scalable, high-fidelity test bed using actual heavy vehicle electronic control units (ECUs), such as engine and brake controllers. Each ECU is wired to a dedicated, combined sensor and actuator simulator component to emulate the communication and electrical environment of a heavy vehicle. The test bed includes built-in mechanisms for remote access and secure information delivery to allow for collaboration among researchers at different sites. Using an Ethernet network adaptor on an embedded microcontroller, the test bed contains an intermediate data processing component that passes and transforms data to and from the ECUs and testbed web application interface. This connectivity allowed for the development of a web application interface for user-specific experiment construction, scheduling, data storage, data retrieval, and visualization providing a full pass through the experimentation platform. From the web application interface, the user can (a) schedule an experiment for a set duration, (b) design the experiment by inserting requested features and instantiating predefined parameters, (c) view the entirety of the CAN log, and (d) view graphic visualizations of the data. For example, the testbed can visualize what would happen when a vehicle drives at 65 mph and the brake is applied all the way to the floor. Denial of service attacks and injection attacks on the truck ECUs can be performed by invoking interface?s ability to send user-defined CAN messages on the bus at set intervals. Using Unified Diagnostic Services (UDS), it is possible to update the engine controller and change the Vehicle Identification Number (VIN). The results of the research, including the potential to extend the test bed with other components, can impact cyber security analysis for other industries that use CAN, such as building automation, medical devices, and manufacturing. In addition to presenting their work in various forums, undergraduate and graduate students working on the project participated in the Society of Automotive Engineering (SAE/Battelle) CyberAuto Challenge in Detroit, MI in July 2018. Students also participated in the second annual CyberTruck Challenge in Warren, Michigan, in June 2018. Weeklong summer boot camps for undergraduates participating in the annual University of Tulsa Undergraduate Research Challenge were conducted in heavy vehicle cyber security to introduce the research area. New graduate courses have been introduced and team-taught by mechanical engineering and computer science faculty to provide a multi-disciplinary perspective on heavy vehicles as cyber physical systems, cyber security, and vehicle communication networks.
